title: Converged authorization
content:
Converged authorization is a solution that enables the tenant admin to manage users, roles, and groups for additional capabilities such as Cloud Management (DND, Cloud Cost Reporting, and Content Store), UCMDB, and Operations Orchestration (OO), from one single user interface – the Service Management agent interface. Normally, the tenant admin assigns roles to groups and then adds users to groups so that users can inherit the role permissions from the groups.

Don’t assign the Business Intelligence Integration or OPB Remote Agent role to account users because it will prevent them from logging in to Agent Interface and Service Portal. 

This topic explains how the solution works, the best practices for using the solution, and how to migrate existing tenants to this solution. 

How it works

The following explains how the solution works.

Roles

In the agent interface, roles have an attribute named Application. When creating a new role, you need to specify a value for the following fields:

  • Name: the display name of the role. When replicating roles from the agent interface to IdM, the system maps this field to the Display name field of the role in IdM. 
  • Code: This field is used for mapping. When replicating roles from the agent interface to IdM, the system maps this field to the Name field of the role in IdM. Note that the Code field doesn't allow space or any of the following special characters: @;:=&<>#{}|`^~%'?"/[].
  • Application: can be one of the values listed in the following table. The Application field identifies the capability to which the role belongs. These capabilities are either installed together with Service Management or installed separately; however, they have something in common – sharing the same IdM with Service Management. 
    When you enable Native SACM, DND, and OO in Suite Administration, the system automatically replicates the seeded roles and groups for UD/UCMDB, DND (DND and Content Store), and OO from IdM to the agent interface.

    When you enable DND in Suite Administration, the system creates seeded roles and groups only for DND and Content Store, not for Cloud Cost Reporting. 

    There's a strict rule that roles can't and mustn't be shared between capabilities.

    Application field value Capability Notes
    SMAX Service Management Indicates it's a Service Management role, which is used to access the agent interface and Service Portal. 
    CMDB Universal Discovery and CMDB (UCMDB) Indicates it's a UD/UCMDB role, which is used to access classic or containerized UD/UCMDB installed for Native SACM. 
    DND Design and Deploy (DND) Indicates it's a DND role. DND is used for Cloud Management. 
    CGRO Cloud Cost Reporting Indicates it's a Cloud Cost Reporting role. CGRO is used for Cloud Management.
    CONTENTSTORE Content Store Indicates it's a DND Content Store role, which is used to access the Content Management area of DND. 
    OO Operation Orchestration (OO)  Indicates it's a role for access to OO Containerized, which is a standalone application that either works with DND or integrates with Service Management. 
    AUDIT Audit Indicates it's a role for access to Audit.

When you save the role, the system automatically prefixes the role with the Application value. For example, [ DND ] Administrator, or [ OO ] Administrators.

For each application, both the Code and Name field values must be unique. 

The following are the mappings of role fields in the agent interface and in IdM.

Field in the agent interface  Field in IdM
Name Display name
Code* Name
Application Application

Groups

Groups don't need an Application attribute because they're associated with roles, which can have different Application values; however, groups have an "Authorized group" flag, which is automatically turned on when you assign one or more roles to a group. 

When creating a group for any of the additional capabilities, select the Functional group type. 

The following are the mappings of group fields in the agent interface and in IdM.

Field in the agent interface  Field in IdM

User principal name*

 Name
Name Display name

* The User principal name field doesn't allow space or any of the following special characters: @;:=&<>#{}|`^~%'?"/[].

When you update an authorized group's properties in the agent interface, the only properties that the system can replicate to IdM are the group's name, group-role relationships, and group memberships.

Different approaches for managing group memberships

There are two ways for managing memberships for an authorized group: in the agent interface or in IdM.

  • You manage memberships for a group in IdM when you want to use IdM's group rule feature to dynamically assign a large number of members to the group for the additional capabilities. Note that you use only IdM's group rule feature to manage group members, for other group management tasks, such as creating a group or changing the group name, you still do these in the agent portal.
  • You manage memberships for a group in the agent interface when you want to directly assign members to the group.

You can manage some groups in IdM and other groups in the agent interface.

Use the tenant-level Group Member Sync flag and the group-level Pull members from IdM flag to control in which system group memberships are managed.

For groups whose memberships are managed in the agent portal, group-member relationship changes are automatically replicated to IdM.

For groups whose memberships are managed in IdM, a scheduled job periodically replicates the group-member relationship changes from IdM to the agent interface.

    Replication of authorization data

    Automatic replication occurs in the following scenarios.

    When deploying a tenant in Suite Administration

    When the suite admin deploys a tenant in Suite Administration, the system replicates the following data from the agent interface to IdM:

    • The out-of-the-box Service Management roles
    • The tenant admin user
    • The relationship between the tenant admin user and the Tenant Admin role.

    Roles replicated from Service Management are mostly read-only in IdM. The only operation that you need to perform on such roles is assigning permissions to capabilities other than Service Management and UD/UCMDB, by using the Associated Permissions field.

     The system doesn't prevent you from updating the Application field, but you shouldn't do this in IdM. Otherwise, the data consistency between IdM and the agent interface will be compromised and this will result in unexpected behavior.

    When enabling DND, OO, or Native SACM in Suite Administration

    When the suite admin enables DND or OO in Suite Administration, the system replicates the seeded out-of-the-box roles and groups and the relationships between users, roles, and groups from IdM to the agent interface. As an example, the following screenshot shows some seeded DND and OO roles replicated to the agent interface.

    When the system provisions a UCMDB customer, the UD/UCMDB out-of-the-box (OOTB) roles with built-in permissions are automatically seeded in IdM. Since UD/UCMDB doesn't have out-of-the-box groups, for each UCMDB customer, the suite admin needs to create a UD/UCMDB admin group in IdM and associate both the UD/UCMDB out-of-the-box SuperAdmin role and the tenant admin user to this group, so that the Service Management tenant admin can access UD/UCMDB with the highest privilege of this UCMDB customer. When the suite admin enables Native SACM for the tenant, Service Management automatically replicates the seeded UD/UCMDB OOTB roles and the UD/UCMDB admin group from IdM to the agent interface. For more information, see UD/UCMDB user management overview.

     The UD/UCMDB admin group is associated with the [CMDB] SuperAdmin role so that the Service Management tenant admin can have the highest privilege of this UCMDB customer. Don't use the [CMDB] TenantAdmin role as this is for the UCMDB tenants, which correspond to the Service Management data domains instead of the Service Management tenants.

    When performing user authorization management tasks in the agent interface

    When you perform typical user authorization management tasks listed in the Best practices section below in the agent interface, the system replicates the roles and groups and their relationships to IdM. The users are already available in IDM. Furthermore, the system also pushes all the relationships of users, groups, and roles to IdM.

    Best practices

    Normally, the out-of-the-box roles and groups for the additional capabilities can satisfy your business needs; if they can't, you must create custom roles from the agent interface, and the system replicates them to IdM at the same time. The created roles are prefixed with their Application value, so that you can easily identify which capability each role belongs to.

    If you create roles or groups directly from the IdM Admin Portal, the system stores them only in IdM, which causes data inconsistency between IdM and the tenant. 

    Typical tasks in the agent interface

    As a best practice, always use the agent interface to create and manage roles and groups. The following are typical tasks you can perform in the agent interface:

    • Create or update groups
    • Create roles
    • Update role permissions (Service Management roles only)
    • Add or remove persons to/from groups (see this section for exceptions)
    • Add or remove roles to/from groups
    • Add or remove roles to/from persons
    • Add or remove groups to/from persons (in the Group membership section) 

    Permission assignment

    You assign permissions for Service Management and the additional capabilities as follows. 

    Service Management

    You assign permissions to Service Management roles from the agent interface. For more information, see Roles.

    UD/UCMDB

    You assign UD/UCMDB role permissions from the UCMDB Local Client. For more information, see the permission granting section in Create UD/UCMDB custom roles, users, and groups.

    Other capabilities

    For capabilities other than Service Management and UCMDB, the suite admin manages their role permissions from the IdM Admin Portal. For details, see the following links:

    • Configure authorization for DND
    • Configure authorization for Content Store
    • Configure authorization OO Containerized

    Limitations

    The converged authorization solution has the following limitations.

    • The "Move tenant" feature in Suite Administration doesn't support converged authorization. The feature imports the authorization data from the source tenant to the target tenant, but the authorization data imported into the target tenant isn't replicated to IdM. 
    • If a group and a user have the same user principal name (UPN), you can't assign roles to that group or user. This issue happens only to existing authorization data from an upgraded system. In new installations, you're not allowed to create a user and a group with the same UPN.
    • When replicating authorization data to IdM, the system skips the Self-Service Restricted Portal User, Self-Service Portal User, and Guest roles. If a group has only one or more of these roles assigned, the system doesn't replicate the group to IdM; if a group has also other roles assigned, the system replicates the group but skips the relationships between the group and any of these three roles. 
      The Self-Service Restricted Portal User, Self-Service Portal User, and Guest roles are Service Portal specific roles, and hence there's no need to replicate them to IdM. 
    • The user principal name of a group or the Code value of a role can't contain special characters, including space, carriage return, and any of the following characters: @;:=&<>#{}|`^~%'?"/[].
    • Some roles have different names in the Agent interface and in IdM. For example, the Tenant Admin Role in the agent interface has a display name of tenantAdmin in IdM. For a list of these roles, see Authorization migration tab.
    • This solution replicates only direct group memberships from IdM. It doesn't replicate group memberships created by LDAP group rules configured in the IdM Admin Portal.

    Migrate authorization data

    If you have one or more of the additional capabilities deployed, you may want to migrate existing authorization data between IdM and the tenant so that converged authorization works for all authorization data of that tenant. A Migrate button is available from Suite Administration: either from the tenant record or from the Configurations tab. You can start the migration process with one click. This process replicates authorization data between IdM and the tenant (the agent interface) so that both sides store the same authorization data. This is a one-time process. Once the two sides store the same data, whenever you create new authorization data from the agent interface, the new data is replicated to IdM simultaneously. For more information, see Authorization migration tab.

    If you have none of the additional capabilities deployed in your environment, there's no need to perform the migration. This is because you can manage Service Management roles, groups, and role permissions directly from the agent interface without the need for the IdM Admin Portal.  

    You can safely run the migration multiple times.
